results.title: Science fiction: Jules Verne to Ray Bradbury... and beyond
results.creator_credit: Center for Humanities and Barbara Winard
results.brief_description: The three parts of these videos give a brief overview of science fiction through history. Clips from films and television programs are used as illustrations. “From Lucian to Jules Verne” traces the beginnings of science fiction in social satire and criticism with the works of Lucian, Thomas More and Swift until Jules Verne revived the genre by tapping into scientific possibilities. “From H. G. Wells to George Orwell” shows how H. G. Wells linked the old and the new science fiction writers, who developed the space opera, magazines, and the science fiction film, culminating in Orwell’s grim visions of the future. “From Isaac Asimov to Arthur C. Clarke” documents the influences of outside factors such as World War II, the cold war, Vietnam and the hippy experience of the 60’s in the works of Asimov, Heinlein, Herbert and Clarke. Teacher’s notes accompany the videos.

results.title: Science close-up: snake hunt
results.brief_description: Students go on a snake hunt in Florida with staff members of the Lincoln Park Zoo. The emphasis throughout is on the many species of snakes found in a relatively small area which provides a variety of living conditions.

results.title: Science and sheep breeding
results.brief_description: The story of the theory and research which lies behind the practical recommendations for a more accurate and efficient method of selecting merino sheep for wool production. If the breeder uses fleece-weighing as well as the usual methods of classing by eye, they can expect to double the rate of increase in fleece weight.

results.title: Science and money
results.creator_credit: BBC, Michael Coyle and Mike Milne
results.brief_description: While this program is about British coinage, the information on coin alloys and the reasoning for notes versus coins remains relevant. Shows coins actually being tested from the basic alloy through the entire production process.

results.title: Science and agriculture: the soy bean
results.brief_description: A study of the interdependence of science and agriculture in modern life. In a fairly detailed study of the soy bean, its cultivation in China and the USA is shown; the processes of extracting soy bean oil, and the preparation and use of soy bean by-products in the home and in industry are shown.

results.title: Sci-five
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, Nicholas Alexander, Russell Porter and Roger Seccombe
results.brief_description: Sci-five is a film about five very different young Australians who share an absorbing curiousity about the world. It contains interviews with Darren Kelly, Geraldine Milroy, Robert Sinclair, Lindy Coulson and Tim Allen. Each of the five has been a finalist in the BHP Science Prize and their projects provide a focus around which we explore their lives in more detail. The film aims to disprove the common assumption that science is “too hard and too boring” an option for young people. It has no objective commentary, using instead the insights of the teenage scientists themselves. A mosaic structure juxtaposes and intercuts their stories to create a rfascinating documentation of ideas and motives.
results.creator_credit_for_label: CSIRO, Nicholas Alexander, Russell Porter and Roger Seccombe
